review: If I could give a 3.5, I would have. Good book, but left me wanting a little, a danger of the VSI series I think.
This book is a very very short introduction, it might be good for people who have never studied biology and molecular biology, but as a biology student it was boring except final chapter.

I thought it was a pretty decent introduction to evolution, considering the limited space available. It is good for giving the basics to the interested reader. I would have liked to have seen a bit more on the origin of life.

'Evolution' gives an entertaining and up-to-date introduction to the subject and provides an overview of current thnking. Rather than follow the traditional format of revisiting all the old chesnuts, and rehashing previous school textbooks on the subject, 'Evolution - A Very Short Introduction' works from the basics through to current problem areas, using numerous fascinating examples including analogies in our modern non-biotic environment; such as the motor-car and computers. A good introduction for the novice; an entertaining read for the biologist.

Sometimes random thoughts enter my head, like, "If I was stopped on the sidewalk and asked to give a convincing and coherent explanation of evolution, could I?" I did actually have this thought a few days ago. So I started running through an explanation in my head. Then whilst at the library poking among the geology books, I saw this. It's time for a quick refresher course.

It is a great guide to introduce one to the subject. It provides the theoretical fundamentals of the theory of evolution along with the evidence that supports it. It also mentions the areas that are not yet supported by evidence and some questions which still remain unanswered. It's a great beginner level book.
I never seem to get bored of evolution books. Informative and very well condensed.

Like the cover says, this is an essential read for anyone interested in understanding Evolution, how Evolution works- described using some nice examples and the key concepts the underlie Evolution. It is not just aimed at students and researchers, but also any lay reader. Further reading of other much more detailed textbooks is highly recommended. This sets the scene for the story of Evolution. I enjoyed reading this as it is quite short and easy to read (language wise) and not too highly priced.

A useful book to understand what evolution through natural selection is, how it works, itโs key concepts and mechanisms, with a bit of history and how the theory of evolution evolved. The book get a bit too technical some time for general readers but itโs not always possible nor useful to simply what is complexe. I do recommend this short introduction.
Good book, but for a technical audience. I have a minir dispute regarding the evolutionary removing of diseases of the elderly. ;)

The book I read to research this post was Evolution A Very Short Introduction by Brian Charlesworth which is a very good book which I bought from kindle. This books tells you all about evolution and how DNA is made up so that you get significent differences in the genetics of an animal or other living thing in roughly 1 in 100,000 and in the wild most of these would die but in some cases they would have enhancements and would become more successful and the species would evolve. An example is on the Galapagos Islands if there is a drought plants that produce small seeds stop producing them to save water but plants that produce a small amount of big seeds still produce them. As a result temporarily birds evolve deep big beaks but once the drought finishes they gradually go back to normal. In rats many have been exterminated by warfarin which is a rat poison. They have developed a tolerance in some to this but they also had stunted growth if they were immune but now appear to have changed genetically in many cases to get around. Warfarin works by preventing the blood from clotting and affects vitamin k platelets in their blood. Evolution of course was discovered by Darwin & an interesting point is there is probably life on other planets in other solar systems. The sun is a fairly typical star of which there are billions of a similiar type in our galaxy and there are billions of galaxies in our universe.

This book is not so much an introduction to evolution as a defense of it against its critics. This is not a normal position, of course, for an established scientific theory to be in, so it is entirely understandable for the authors to be suspicious of their readers' motives. Moreover, they consequently manage to inform the reader far better than if they had simply preached. Perhaps would-be popularisers of more complacent scientific disciplines could learn from them.

Maybe if you know nothing about anything related to evolution, this would be okay. But if you know even a little, this is just not enough: too simplified, no clear references to where facts are from in order to learn more. It also may need a new edition; 2003 is getting pretty long in the tooth for evolution.And the authors are wrong here: it should be Brian Charlesworth and Deborah Charlesworth.

The authors do a wonderful job of breaking down the science of evolution to the basics. However, I had to re-read some sections several times to make sure I grasped the concepts (should have taken biology instead of Latin in high school).It's amazing how modern science, especially genetics and the study of DNA, has validated Darwin's postulations, and it underscores his genius.

Helpful and informative. At times it gets jargony, but it gives you a feel for the basics of evolution. The final chapter examines some of the problems (and alleged problems) that the theory faces. I haven't had a biology class since 1986, so I needed to brush up.
Evolution in short and condensed words.
I am reading it on my Kindle. It is an interesting overview of the ins and outs of evolution, how it works and why nothing in biology makes sense without the theory.
